DOCNAME: CASE OF JURISIC AND COLLEGIUM MEHRERAU v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violations of Art. 6-1;Not necessary to examine further complaint under Art. 6-1;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention and domestic proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The second applicant wished to employ the first applicant as a farm hand .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged a request with ORG Arbeitsmarktservice ) for the grant of an employment permit to the second applicant . They submitted that the first applicant , a national of GPE , and his wife had been resident in GPE since DATE . Both he and his wife had been granted residence permits ( GPE ) that were valid until DATE . The applicants claimed that the first applicant had a right to take up employment in GPE . They referred in that connection to FAC and ORG between ORG and GPE and submitted that those treaties had to be applied by analogy to their case .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the request in accordance with s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG ( GPE ) . It found that the maximum quota fixed for the employment of foreign workers in PERSON had been exceeded and none of the conditions for making an exception under s. CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW were met .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed . They reiterated the arguments they had submitted before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the first applicant ’s appeal as inadmissible . It noted that only the second applicant as the proposed employer , not the first applicant , had the right to lodge a request for the grant of an employment permit . According to s. CARDINAL of ORG an alien only became a party to proceedings concerning the issue of a work permit if his personal circumstances were relevant to the decision or if there was no employer . In the present case , however , neither of these conditions applied . In particular , ORG had based its decision exclusively on the situation of the labour market , and in particular the fact that the maximum quota for the employment of foreign workers had been exceeded . For that reason , the first applicant was not a party to the proceedings .

CARDINAL . ORG further noted that only certain refugees DATE namely , those who had indefinite leave to remain , were married to an NORP national or had a child of NORP nationality – were exempted from the regulations of ORG . The first applicant did not fall into any of those categories . ORG between ORG and GPE was not applicable in the present case as the first applicant was not a NORP national .

CARDINAL . ORG went on to dismiss the second applicant ’s appeal . It observed that ORG had proposed a replacement for the first applicant within the meaning of s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of ORG , but he had not been taken on . In a telephone conversation ORG had been informed by a representative of the second applicant that the proposed replacement had not been employed because the relevant post had already been filled . In further submissions the second applicant stated that the replacement had not complied with the requirements of the post .

CARDINAL . ORG concluded that the second applicant had no further interest in employing the first applicant . It observed in particular that the second applicant had not given sufficient reasons as to why the proposed replacement could not work as a farm hand , a post which did not require any special qualification . It concluded that the second applicant was not interested in employing a replacement and dismissed the request for an employment permit under s. CARDINAL ) of LAW . It further noted that , in any event , the conditions for granting an employment permit had not been satisfied as the maximum quota fixed for the employment of foreign workers in PERSON had been exceeded and none of the conditions for an exception under s. CARDINAL ) of the above LAW applied .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants filed a complaint with ORG and requested an oral hearing . They submitted that ORG had not carried out sufficient investigations before reaching its findings . In particular , it had not heard evidence from the second applicant . They further denied that the second applicant had informed ORG that the relevant post had been filled , and contested the maximum quota .

CARDINAL . Referring to LAW , ORG between ORG and GPE , LAW , LAW and LAW , the applicants submitted that the first applicant had a right to take up employment in GPE and had standing to join the proceedings . They also relied on DATE CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . They submitted that the first applicant had come to GPE as a NORP refugee , had resided there with his wife since DATE and was in possession of a residence permit that was valid until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the first applicant ’s complaint and dismissed the second applicant ’s complaint . It found that none of the first applicant ’s rights had been violated , as the refusal to grant the employment permit was not based on reasons related to the first applicant ’s personal circumstances under s. CARDINAL of ORG .

CARDINAL . As to the second applicant ’s complaint , it found that ORG decision was coherent and conclusive . ORG had based its decision essentially on the statements of the second applicant . There had , therefore , been no further need to hear representations from the second applicant . ORG concluded that ORG had rightly refused to issue an employment permit DATE ( CARDINAL ) of ORG . It also decided that it was unnecessary to examine the second applicant ’s further submissions questioning whether the maximum quota had been attained .

CARDINAL . ORG further noted that the second applicant had never alleged that the first applicant was a refugee within the meaning of LAW . As regards the reference to LAW and LAW , it noted that those treaties were not directly applicable and so could not create any subjective rights . At most , they might be of assistance in interpreting the domestic legislation . However , having regard to the clear wording of s. CARDINAL of ORG and the fact that there was no prospect of that provision being successfully challenged in ORG ) , as that court had already ruled that proceedings concerning a request for an employment permit under LAW did not concern a “ civil right or obligation ” within the meaning of LAW , the Administrative Court said that even the above mentioned interpretation would not lead to recognition of the first applicant ’s legal standing in the proceedings concerning the grant of an employment permit .
CARDINAL . It went on to note that ORG between ORG and GPE was not applicable as the first applicant was not NORP .

CARDINAL . In accordance with s. CARDINAL ) of LAW ( PERSON ) , ORG dismissed the ORG request for a hearing as it found that an oral hearing was not likely to contribute to the clarification of the case . Referring to its case - law it further found that the proceedings did not concern a “ civil right ” within the meaning of LAW . The decision was served on the applicants’ counsel on DATE .
CARDINAL . The second applicant was subsequently granted a permit to employ the first applicant from DATE until DATE and from DATE until DATE .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant ’s wife became an NORP citizen . Consequently , ORG is no longer applicable to the first applicant .
CARDINAL . The Employment of Aliens Act ( ORG ) regulates an alien ’s access to the NORP labour market . The relevant parts of the Act at the material time were as follows :
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL stated that the LAW was not applicable inter alia to :
- certain refugees who had indefinite leave to remain in GPE , who were married to an NORP national or who had a child of NORP nationality ( s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) ) ;

- aliens married to an NORP national if they were in possession of a residence document ( ORG ) within the meaning of LAW ( s. CARDINAL ) ) ; under LAW ( PERSON ) there are CARDINAL types of residence document : residence permits ( GPE ) and settlement permits ( Niederlassungsbewilligung ) . The relevant provisions of LAW make it easier for aliens married to an NORP national to obtain a settlement permit .
Under s. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG the competent ORG had to certify that the alien concerned fulfilled the requirements of s. MONEY ) before he could take up employment .

CARDINAL . S. CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW laid down the principle that a proposed employer required an employment permit ( PERSON ) if he wished to take on a foreign employee . Without such a permit the contract of employment between the employer and the foreign employee was null and void . However , while he was actually employed an alien hired without an employment permit had the same rights against his employer as he would have had if the contract of employment had been valid . If the lack of an employment permit was due to the employer ’s negligence , the foreign employee further enjoyed all the rights to which he would have been entitled upon the termination of a valid employment relationship ( s. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . S. CARDINAL of the Act provided that a request could be made for an “ exemption certificate ” ( PERSON ) in respect of aliens who had been continuously legally employed within the meaning of the LAW in GPE for DATE during DATE , and for aliens who had been married to an NORP national for DATE and had their residence ( ORG ) in GPE . The exemption certificate subsequently relieved the alien or potential employer from the obligation to apply for an employment permit . S. CARDINAL provided that the alien concerned could apply for an exemption certificate to the competent ORG .

CARDINAL . If an alien had been continuously legally employed within the meaning of the LAW for DATE in DATE , he was entitled to request a personal work permit ( Arbeitserlaubnis ) which was normally valid for CARDINAL region only and could be restricted to certain kinds of employment ( s. CARDINAL ( a ) ) .

CARDINAL . S. CARDINAL provided that in order to obtain an employment permit the employer had to submit details of the proposed employment of the individual employee to ORG concerned . The application could be made by the alien only if there was no employer .

CARDINAL . According to s. CARDINAL ) an employment permit could only be granted if the situation and evolution of the labour market so allowed and important public or economic interests would not be harmed . Furthermore , specific conditions listed in s. CARDINAL ) had to be fulfilled .

CARDINAL . S. CARDINAL(b)(CARDINAL ) laid down that the situation and evolution of the labour market only allowed an employment permit to be granted in respect of a proposed foreign employee if there were no prior - ranking foreign job applicants . Prior - ranking foreign job applicants included aliens who were in possession of an exemption certificate within the meaning of s. CARDINAL of the LAW or who were in receipt of unemployment insurance payments ( PERSON ) ( s. CARDINAL(b)(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . S. CARDINAL(c ) provided that an employment permit had to be issued ex officio in respect of NORP nationals falling within the relevant provisions of ORG between ORG and GPE .

CARDINAL . Under s. CARDINAL ) the Minister for ORG could fix maximum quotas for the employment of aliens in a specific region ( PERSON ) for DATE . PERSON ) provided that once the maximum quota had been exhausted , no further employment permits could be issued unless there were certain exceptional circumstances .

CARDINAL . S. DATE provided that , in principle , the foreign job applicant was not a party to the proceedings concerning the issue of the employment permit . Exceptions were made where the personal circumstances of the alien were relevant to the decision or where there was no employer .

CARDINAL . According to the settled case - law of ORG and ORG a refusal to issue an employment permit under PERSON CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of ORG could not violate a proposed foreign employee ’s rights because he had no legal entitlement to the grant under that LAW ( see PERSON , PERSON DATE ; and ORG decision of DATE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG and ORG have further held that the refusal of an employment permit to a proposed employer is not a decision concerning the employer ’s “ civil rights ” ( see , for example , PERSON DATE and ORG decision of DATE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL with further references ) .

CARDINAL . According to s. CARDINAL ) of LAW , ORG must hold a hearing after its preliminary investigation of the case if a complainant so requests within the time - limit . PERSON ) and ( CARDINAL ) provides , however , that , notwithstanding such a request , ORG may decide not to hold a hearing if it is apparent from the written pleadings of the parties and the files relating to the previous proceedings that an oral hearing is unlikely to help clarify the case and that the lack of a hearing will not violate LAW .
